questions.question: What is the total cumulative net increase (decrease) from available-for-sale securities for Adobe Inc. (ADBE) over the three fiscal years ending November 29, 2024, December 1, 2023, and December 2, 2022, and how does this trend compare to the changes in unrealized gains/losses on those securities?
questions.answer: The total cumulative net increase (decrease) from available-for-sale securities for Adobe Inc. (ADBE) over the three fiscal years is $-9 million. This is calculated by summing the net increases/decreases: $11 million (2024) + $29 million (2023) + $(-39) million (2022) = $-9 million. The unrealized gains/losses on available-for-sale securities were $11 million (2024), $24 million (2023), and $(-39) million (2022), which closely aligns with the net changes, indicating minimal impact from reclassification adjustments over the period.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Net increase (decrease) from available-for-sale securities for 2024: $11 million
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_a - Net increase (decrease) from available-for-sale securities for 2023: $29 million
Step 3: Extract from evidence_source_a - Net increase (decrease) from available-for-sale securities for 2022: $-39 million
Step 4: Extract from evidence_source_b - Unrealized gains/losses on available-for-sale securities for 2024: $11 million
Step 5: Extract from evidence_source_b - Unrealized gains/losses on available-for-sale securities for 2023: $24 million
Step 6: Extract from evidence_source_b - Unrealized gains/losses on available-for-sale securities for 2022: $-39 million

Step 7: Synthesize - Sum the net increases/decreases from all three years: $11M + $29M + (-$39M) = $-9M. Compare with unrealized gains/losses which sum to $11M + $24M + (-$39M) = $-4M, showing minimal reclassification adjustments.

questions.question: What specific strategic growth opportunities does Adobe identify in its Digital Experience segment for fiscal 2025 and beyond, and how does its Adobe Experience Platform enhance these opportunities through real-time customer profiles and AI-driven insights?
questions.answer: Adobe identifies strategic growth opportunities in its Digital Experience segment for fiscal 2025 and beyond, including delivering on-brand, customer engagement, growth within existing customer accounts, product differentiation, and offering the best customer experience management solutions for B2B and B2C buyers across enterprise and mid-market segments. Adobe Experience Cloud, powered by Adobe Experience Platform, enhances these opportunities by transforming customer data from Adobe solutions and third-party software into robust, real-time customer profiles. These profiles are enriched with AI-driven insights, enabling brands to deliver personalized customer experiences across channels. This open architecture also allows businesses to develop innovative apps for customer interaction and supports a broad industry ecosystem, thereby increasing the value delivered to customers and creating competitive differentiation in the market.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Adobe organizes its business into three segments, one of which is the Digital Experience segment, aligned with strategic growth opportunities.

Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Adobe Experience Cloud, part of the Digital Experience segment, focuses on delivering personalized digital experiences using AI and real-time customer profiles.

Step 3: Synthesize - Adobe Experience Platform enables real-time customer profiling and AI-driven insights, which support the strategic growth opportunities outlined in the Digital Experience segment.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

marketing campaigns and personalized customer experiences. We believe we are well positioned to deliver value in both the Digital Media and Digital Experience strategic areas where our mission to change the world through personalized digital experiences has never been more relevant as people seek new ways to create, collaborate and communicate and businesses continue to invest in digital transformation.

## SEGMENTS

Our business is organized into three reportable segments:

- Digital Media;
- Digital Ex perience; and
- Publishing and Advertising.

These segments provide Adobe's senior management with a comprehensive financial view of our key businesses. Our segments are aligned around our two strategic growth opportunities further described below, and our legacy products, services and solutions are contained within the third segment, Publishing and Advertising.

## MARKET OVERVIEW

This overview provides an explanation of our markets and a discussion of strategic opportunities in fiscal 2025 and beyond for each of our segments. See the section titled 'Results of Operations' in Part II, Item 7 titled 'Management' s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations' and Note 2 of our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements of this report for further segment information.

## Digital Media

## Opportunity

In today's digital world, content and digital documents are fueling the global economy, and productivity, design and creativity have never been more relevant, providing a significant market opportunity for Adobe in digital media. Everyone has a story to tell and needs products and services at their fingertips to tell those stories on an ever-increasing number of canvases. AI- and generative AI-powered technologies are increasing this opportunity by growing the demand for and production of content. This shift is changing how creative professionals work by accelerating their processes, increasing their productivity, and allowing them to explore and create in new fields, while empowering new creators by dramatically lowering barriers to creativity. At the same time, creativity is increasingly a team effort that is redefining productivity, making quick and easy collaboration even more critical to every company's success. Adobe is driving innovation to shape these trends, democratize creativity, empower individuals to create wherever inspiration strikes and enable more effective collaboration between creators and stakeholders.

The  flagship  of  our  Digital  Media  business  is Adobe  Creative  Cloud,  a  subscription  service  that  allows  subscribers  to  use  our  creative  products  and applications ('Apps') integrated with cloud-delivered services across various surfaces and platforms. We believe in creativity for all, and Creative Cloud addresses the needs of all content creators, from creative professionals, such as artists, designers, developers, students, and administrators, to knowledge workers, marketers, educators,  enthusiasts,  communicators,  and  consumers.  Our  customers  rely  on  our  products  for  content  creation,  photo  editing,  design,  video  and  animation production, mobile App and gaming development, and more. Our customers can choose between products optimized for different platforms and capabilities, from the speed and ease of use offered by Adobe Express, our AI-first, task-based web and mobile App, to the greater power and precision of our flagship Creative Cloud Apps.  We believe we have significant opportunities to grow our  Digital  Media business by advancing every creative category across all surfaces; expanding content-first, task-based creativity with Adobe Express; enabling seamless collaboration across all stakeholders; inspiring the creative community through sharing and monetization; and expanding the user base of our tools through the infusion of AI into our products, services and solutions to enable users of any skill level to easily and efficiently create content.

Our  Digital  Media  segment  includes  our Adobe  Document  Cloud  business,  a  unified,  cloud-based  document  services  platform  that  integrates Adobe's pioneering PDF technology with our Adobe Acrobat, Adobe Scan and Adobe Acrobat Sign Apps to deliver fully digital document workflows across all surfaces. We have the opportunity to continue to accelerate document productivity with Adobe Document Cloud and transform how people view, share, collaborate, and engage with documents. Trillions of PDF documents are created every year, reflecting the important role PDF plays globally. There are hundreds of millions of users who engage with PDF files on a daily basis in industries such as legal, financial services, and publishing, as well as a broad array of communicators and Adobe Acrobat Reader customers who use the expanded capabilities provided by our Acrobat Apps and the document services platform in Adobe Document Cloud.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

manage, collaborate and execute on workflows for marketing campaigns and other projects at speed and scale; and leverage self-serve capabilities to deliver on-brand content.

- Customer journeys . Our products help businesses manage, test, target and personalize customer journeys delivered as campaigns across B2B and B2C use cases.

Our goal is to deploy our capabilities to help enterprises generate highly engaging experiences, enable content creators to enhance creativity and scale content production, and provide marketing strategists with recommendations to improve marketing strategy and enhance the delivery of personalized customer journeys. In our Adobe Experience Cloud, we believe our innovations, natively embedded AI services, and end-to-end content supply chain solutions enhance the delivery and personalization of digital ex periences by allowing our customers to gain insights and understand their data, simulate outcomes, automate tasks, generate audiences, create content, optimize marketing campaigns and enable the delivery of more relevant and personalized customer journeys. Adobe Experience Cloud offers domain-specific AI services in areas such as attribution and automated insights, customer journey management, lead management, sentiment analysis, oneclick  personalization, enhanced anomaly detection and more that work with Adobe Experience Platform to augment our Experience Cloud product offerings. By building on these features and capabilities, we increase the value we provide our customers and create a competitive differentiation in the market.

Adobe Experience Cloud offers an open platform and ecosystem through Adobe Experience Platform. Adobe Experience Platform's open system transforms businesses' customer data from across their Adobe solutions and third-party software into robust customer profiles. These profiles are updated in real time and include AI-driven  insights,  allowing  a  brand  to  deliver  the  right  customer  ex periences  across  channels  and  deliver  true  one-to-one  personalization.  This  open architecture offers scalability with a wide variety of supporting products and services and empowers businesses to quickly develop innovative Apps to interact with their customers and enables a broad industry ecosystem.

To drive growth of Adobe Experience Cloud, we focus on delivering on-brand, customer engagement, growth within existing customer accounts, product differentiation and the best customer experience management solutions for B2B and B2C buyers across enterprise and mid-market segments. We intend to pursue growth  through  a  scaled  go-to-market  approach  focused  on  C-suite  partnerships,  transformational  accounts,  continued  customer  acquisition,  customer  value realization and solution ex pansion. We utilize a direct sales force to market and license our Ex perience Cloud solutions, as well as an ex tensive ecosystem of partners, including marketing agencies, systems integrators and independent software vendors that help license and deploy our solutions to their customers. We also maintain several strategic partnerships with other technology companies that allow us to increase our market reach. We have made significant investments to broaden the scale and size of all these routes to market and believe these investments will result in continued growth in revenue in our Digital Experience segment in fiscal 2025 and beyond.

## Publishing and Advertising

Our Publishing and Advertising segment contains legacy products and services that address diverse market opportunities including eLearning solutions, technical document publishing, web conferencing, document and forms platform, web App development, high-end printing and our Adobe Advertising offerings. Graphics professionals and professional publishers continue to require quality, reliability and efficiency in production printing, and our Adobe PostScript and Adobe PDF printing technologies provide advanced functionality to meet the sophisticated requirements of this marketplace. As high-end printing systems evolve and transition to fully digital, composite workflows, we believe we are well positioned to be a supplier of software and technology based on the Adobe PostScript and Adobe PDF standards for this industry.

Adobe Advertising delivers an end-to-end, demand-side platform for managing advertising across digital formats and simplifies the delivery of video, display and search advertising across channels and screens.

We generate revenue in our legacy Publishing products and services by licensing our technology to original equipment manufacturers that manufacture workflow software, printers and other output devices, and we generally generate revenue in Advertising through usage-based offerings.

## COMPETITION

## Overview

We participate in a rapidly evolving, highly competitive global environment, where our competitors vary by industry and range from large multinational enterprises to smaller entities with specialized and focused product offerings. Across our business, we recognize hundreds of competitors worldwide. The markets for our products and services are characterized by new industry standards, evolving distribution models, rapid technological innovation, frequent product introductions and short

questions.question: What was Adobe's total net increase from derivatives designated as hedging instruments over the three fiscal years ending November 29, 2024, December 1, 2023, and December 2, 2022?
questions.answer: Adobe's total net increase from derivatives designated as hedging instruments over the three fiscal years was $65 million. This is calculated by summing the individual net increases/(decreases) from derivatives across the three years: $106 million (2024) + ($43 million decrease in 2023) + ($12 million decrease in 2022) = $65 million.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - The net increase from derivatives designated as hedging instruments for the fiscal year ending November 29, 2024, was $106 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - The net decrease from derivatives designated as hedging instruments for the fiscal year ending December 1, 2023, was ($43) million.
Step 3: Extract from both chunks - The net decrease from derivatives designated as hedging instruments for the fiscal year ending December 2, 2022, was ($12) million.
Step 4: Synthesize - To determine the total net increase over the three fiscal years, sum the individual values: $106 + ($-43) + ($-12) = $65 million.

questions.question: What was the total impact of unrealized gains/losses on derivative instruments and reclassification adjustments on Adobe's comprehensive income in 2024, and how did this compare to the prior year?
questions.answer: In 2024, the total impact of unrealized gains on derivative instruments and reclassification adjustments was $106 million, which significantly increased Adobe's comprehensive income compared to a decrease of $43 million in 2023. This represents a $149 million swing in favor of 2024.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Unrealized gains on derivative instruments in 2024 were $89 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_a - Reclassification adjustment for realized gains on derivative instruments in 2024 was $17 million.
Step 3: Extract from evidence_source_b - Unrealized losses on derivative instruments in 2023 were $(12) million.
Step 4: Extract from evidence_source_b - Reclassification adjustment for realized losses on derivative instruments in 2023 was $(31) million.
Step 5: Calculate total impact for 2024: $89 million (unrealized gains) + $17 million (reclassification adjustment) = $106 million.
Step 6: Calculate total impact for 2023: $(12) million (unrealized losses) + $(31) million (reclassification adjustment) = $(43) million.
Step 7: Calculate year-over-year change: $106 million (2024) - $(43) million (2023) = $149 million increase.

questions.question: By how much did Apple's Products Gross Margin dollar amount increase in 2024 compared to 2023, and what were the primary factors contributing to this increase according to the company's analysis?
questions.answer: Apple's Products Gross Margin increased by $830 million in 2024 compared to 2023 ($109,633 million - $108,803 million = $830 million). The increase was primarily due to cost savings, although this was partially offset by a different Products mix and the weakness in foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - The Products Gross Margin for 2024 was $109,633 million and for 2023 was $108,803 million.
Step 2: Calculate the difference - $109,633 million - $108,803 million = $830 million increase.

Step 3: Extract from evidence_source_b - The company attributed the increase to cost savings, partially offset by a different Products mix and the weakness in foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Products Gross M argin

Products gross margin and Products gross margin percentage increased during 2024 compared to 2023 due to cost savings, partially offset by a different Products mix and the weakness in foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar.

## Services Gross M argin

Services gross margin increased during 2024 compared to 2023 due primarily to higher Services net sales.

Services gross margin percentage increased during 2024 compared to 2023 due to a different Services mix.

The Company's future gross margins can be impacted by a variety of factors, as discussed in Part I, Item 1A  of this Form 10-K under the heading 'Risk Factors.' As a result, the Company believes, in general, gross margins will be subject to volatility and downward pressure.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## NOTE 14 - Segment Reporting

Management, including the Chief Operating Decision Maker, who is the Company's Chief Executive Officer, reviews and  assesses  operating  performance  using  segment  net  revenue  and  operating  income  (loss).  These  performance measures include the allocation of expenses to the operating segments based on management's judgment.

The Company has the following two reportable segments:

- the  Computing  and  Graphics  segment,  which  primarily  includes  desktop  and  notebook  microprocessors, accelerated  processing  units that integrate  microprocessors  and  graphics,  chipsets,  discrete  graphics processing units (GPUs), data center and professional GPUs, and development services. From time to time, the Company may also sell or license portions of its IP portfolio.
- the  Enterprise,  Embedded  and  Semi-Custom  segment,  which  primarily  includes  server  and  embedded processors, semi-custom SoC products, development services and technology for game consoles. From time to time, the Company may also sell or license portions of its IP portfolio.

In addition to these reportable segments, the Company has an All Other category, which is not a reportable segment. This category primarily includes certain expenses and credits that are not allocated to any of the reportable segments because management does not consider these expenses and credits in evaluating the performance of the reportable segments.  This  category  primarily  includes  employee  stock-based  compensation  expense  and  acquisition-related costs.

The following table provides a summary of net revenue and operating income (loss) by segment for 2021, 2020 and 2019.

questions.question: What is the difference in EBT margin percentage between Qualcomm's total revenues and licensing revenues in 2024, and what does this margin differential suggest about the relative profitability of these business segments?
questions.answer: The EBT margin for Qualcomm's total revenues in 2024 was 29%, while the EBT margin for licensing revenues was significantly higher at 72%, resulting in a 43 percentage point difference. This substantial margin differential indicates that Qualcomm's licensing segment is far more profitable on a relative basis compared to its overall business, which includes handsets, automotive, and IoT. The high licensing margin contributes favorably to overall profitability, especially given that licensing revenues accounted for $5.572 billion of the total $33.196 billion in revenues.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, extract the EBT margin for total revenues in 2024, which is 29%.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, extract the EBT margin for licensing revenues in 2024, which is 72%.
Step 3: Calculate the difference between the two margins: 72% - 29% = 43 percentage points.

Step 4: Interpret the margin differential in the context of business segment profitability, noting that licensing revenues, although a smaller portion of total revenues, contribute disproportionately to profitability.

questions.question: By how much did Qualcomm's IoT revenue decrease in 2024 compared to 2023, and what was the corresponding increase in total revenues during the same period?
questions.answer: Qualcomm's IoT revenue decreased by $517 million in 2024 compared to 2023, while its total revenues increased by $2,814 million during the same period.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, extract the change in IoT revenue: (517) million dollars from $5,940 million in 2023 to $5,423 million in 2024.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, extract the total revenue change: $2,814 billion increase from $30,382 million in 2023 to $33,196 million in 2024.
Step 3: Synthesize both figures to answer the question, showing both the decline in IoT revenue and the overall growth in total revenues.

reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, extract the 2023 values: Benefit from FDII deduction (excluding R&D capitalization) is $447 million and Benefit from FDII deduction (related to R&D capitalization) is $598 million.

Step 3: Calculate the total FDII benefit for each year: 2023 = $447 million + $598 million = $1,045 million; 2024 = $596 million + $585 million = $1,181 million.
Step 4: Add the total FDII benefits for both years: $1,045 million (2023) + $1,181 million (2024) = $2,226 million.

questions.question: What was the dollar amount of the decline in Qualcomm's IoT (internet of things) revenue from 2023 to 2024, and how did this decline contribute to the overall change in total QCT revenues during the same period?
questions.answer: Qualcomm's IoT revenue declined by $517 million from 2023 ($5,940 million) to 2024 ($5,423 million). This decline was partially offset by increases in other business segments, particularly Automotive (up $1,038 million) and Handsets (up $2,293 million), which together contributed to an overall increase in total QCT revenues of $2,814 million.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - IoT revenue in 2023 was $5,940 million and in 2024 was $5,423 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - The change in IoT revenue was a decrease of $517 million.
Step 3: Extract from evidence_source_b - Total revenues increased by $2,814 million, with Handsets contributing $2,293 million and Automotive contributing $1,038 million.
Step 4: Synthesize - The $517 million decline in IoT revenue was more than offset by growth in other segments, resulting in a net revenue increase of $2,814 million.

Step 2: Extract from source B - The 2024 Non-U.S. Rate of Increase in Future Compensation for Net Periodic Pension Expense is 5.13%.

questions.question: What is the difference in the Interest Crediting Rate for Net Periodic Pension Expense for Non-U.S. Pension Plans between fiscal years 2024 and 2023, and how does this change compare to the change observed between fiscal years 2023 and 2022?
questions.answer: The Interest Crediting Rate for Net Periodic Pension Expense for Non-U.S. Pension Plans increased by 0.22 percentage points from fiscal year 2023 (1.37%) to 2024 (1.59%). In comparison, the rate increased by 0.60 percentage points from fiscal year 2022 (0.77%) to 2023 (1.37%). The change from 2023 to 2024 is significantly smaller than the prior year-over-year increase.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - The Interest Crediting Rate for Net Periodic Pension Expense for Non-U.S. Pension Plans in fiscal year 2024 is 1.59%.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - The Interest Crediting Rate for Net Periodic Pension Expense for Non-U.S. Pension Plans in fiscal year 2023 is 1.37%, and in fiscal year 2022 is 0.77%.
Step 3: Calculate the difference between 2024 and 2023: 1.59% - 1.37% = 0.22%.
Step 4: Calculate the difference between 2023 and 2022: 1.37% - 0.77% = 0.60%.
Step 5: Compare the two changes: The increase from 2023 to 2024 (0.22%) is smaller than the increase from 2022 to 2023 (0.60%).

questions.question: How has the Embedded segment's operating margin trended from 2022 to 2024, and what does this indicate about the segment's cost management relative to its revenue changes?
questions.answer: The Embedded segment's operating margin decreased from 49.5% in 2022 ($2,252M operating income on $4,552M net revenue) to 49.3% in 2023 ($2,628M operating income on $5,321M net revenue), and further declined to 40.0% in 2024 ($1,421M operating income on $3,557M net revenue). This indicates that while revenue declined significantly in 2024, operating income fell even more sharply, suggesting deteriorating cost management or increased cost pressures despite lower revenue.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, extract Embedded segment net revenue and operating income for 2022 ($4,552M revenue, $2,252M operating income), 2023 ($5,321M revenue, $2,628M operating income), and 2024 ($3,557M revenue, $1,421M operating income).
Step 2: Calculate operating margins for each year by dividing operating income by net revenue: 2022 (2,252 / 4,552 = 49.5%), 2023 (2,628 / 5,321 = 49.3%), and 2024 (1,421 / 3,557 = 40.0%).

Step 3: From evidence_source_b, observe that Embedded segment goodwill remains relatively stable (from $21,055M in 2022 to $21,072M in 2024), indicating no major acquisitions or write-downs affecting the trend.

Step 4: Synthesize: The declining operating margin despite stable goodwill suggests that the drop in profitability is operationally driven, not due to acquisition-related costs, pointing to challenges in managing costs relative to revenue declines.

questions.question: What was the dollar increase in AMD's Marketing, General and Administrative Expenses in 2024, and by what percentage did this increase occur as the company expanded its go-to-market activities to support revenue growth?
questions.answer: AMD's Marketing, General and Administrative Expenses increased by $431 million, or 18%, in 2024 compared to 2023, as the company expanded its go-to-market activities to support revenue growth.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Marketing, general and administrative expenses of $2.8 billion in 2024 increased by $431 million, or 18%, compared to $2.4 billion in 2023.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - The increase was primarily due to an increase in go-to-market activities to support revenue growth.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Gross Margin

Gross margin as a percentage of net rev enue was 49% in 2024 compared to 46% in 2023. The increase in gross margin was due to a fav orable shift in rev enue mix of higher Data Center and Client rev enues, lower Gaming rev enue, partially offset by the impact of lower Embedded rev enue.

## Expenses

## Research and Development Expenses

Research and development expenses of $6.5 billion in 2024 increased by $584 million, or 10%, compared to $5.9 billion in 2023. The increase was primarily due to higher employee-related costs due to an increase in headcount in support of our AI strategy.

## Marketing, General and Administrative Expenses

Marketing, general and administrativ e expenses of $2.8 billion in 2024 increased by $431 million, or 18%, compared to $2.4 billion in 2023. T he increase was primarily due to an increase in go-to-market activ ities to support our rev enue growth.

## Amortization of Acquisition-Related Intangibles

Amortization of acquisition-related intangibles of $2.4 billion for 2024 decreased by $417 million, or 15%, compared to $2.8 billion in 2023. T he decrease was primarily due to certain acquisition-related intangibles being fully amortized in the prior fiscal year.

## Restructuring Charges

We recognized $186 million of restructuring charges in 2024 due to the implementation of a restructuring plan (the 2024 Restructuring Plan). The 2024 Restructuring Plan was focused on driv ing efficiencies across the business and aligning resources with our largest growth opportunities in the AI and enterprise markets.

## Licensing Gain

We hold equity interests in two joint v entures (collectiv ely, the THATIC JV) with Higon Information T echnology Co., Ltd. (THATIC), a third-party Chinese entity. We recognized $48 million and $34 million of licensing gain from royalty income associated with the licensed IP to the THATIC JV, in 2024 and 2023, respectiv ely.

questions.question: How much did AVGO's dividends to preferred stockholders decrease between fiscal year 2022 and fiscal year 2023, and what was the change in dividends to common stockholders during the same period?
questions.answer: AVGO's dividends to preferred stockholders decreased by $299 million between fiscal year 2022 and fiscal year 2023, as there were no dividends paid to preferred stockholders in fiscal year 2023. During the same period, dividends to common stockholders increased from $6,733 million in fiscal year 2022 to $7,645 million in fiscal year 2023, representing an increase of $912 million.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Dividends to preferred stockholders were $299 million in fiscal year 2022 and $0 in fiscal year 2023.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Dividends to common stockholders were $6,733 million in fiscal year 2022 and $7,645 million in fiscal year 2023.
Step 3: Calculate the decrease in dividends to preferred stockholders: $299 million (2022) - $0 (2023) = $299 million decrease.
Step 4: Calculate the increase in dividends to common stockholders: $7,645 million (2023) - $6,733 million (2022) = $912 million increase.

Step 5: Synthesize - The company shifted its dividend policy from paying preferred stockholders in 2022 to focusing entirely on common stockholders in 2023, while also increasing the payout to common stockholders.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table	of	Contents

## PART	II

## ITEM	5. MARKET	FOR	REGISTRANT'S	COMMON	EQUITY,	RELATED	STOCKHOLDER	MATTERS	AND	ISSUER	PURCHASES	OF	EQUITY	SECURITIES

## Market	Information

Broadcom	common	stock	is	listed	on	The	Nasdaq	Global	Select	Market	under	the	symbol	'AVGO'.

## Holders

As	of	November	29,	2024,	there	were	1,735	holders	of	record	of	our	common	stock.	A	substantially	greater	number	of stockholders	are	'street	name'	or	beneficial	holders,	whose	shares	are	held	of	record	by	banks,	brokers	and	other	financial institutions.

## Issuer	Purchases	of	Equity	Securities

During	the	fiscal	quarter	ended	November	3,	2024,	we	paid	approximately	$1,204	million	in	employee	withholding	taxes	due upon	the	vesting	of	net	settled	equity	awards.	We	withheld	approximately	8	million	shares	of	common	stock	from	employees	in connection	with	such	net	share	settlement	at	an	average	price	of	$160.31	per	share.	These	shares	may	be	deemed	to	be	'issuer purchases'	of	shares.

In	December	2021,	our	Board	of	Directors	authorized	a	stock	repurchase	program	to	repurchase	up	to	$10	billion	of	our common	stock	from	time	to	time	through	December	31,	2022,	which	was	subsequently	extended	to	December	31,	2023.	In	May	2022, our	Board	of	Directors	authorized	another	stock	repurchase	program	to	repurchase	up	to	an	additional	$10	billion	of	our common	stock	from	time	to	time	through	December	31,	2023.	All	$20	billion	of	the	authorized	amount	under	these	stock repurchase	programs	was	utilized	prior	to	expiration	on	December	31,	2023.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
On	September	30,	2019,	we	completed	an	offering	of	approximately	4	million	shares	of	Mandatory	Convertible	Preferred Stock,	which	generated	net	proceeds	of	approximately	$3,679	million	and	would	automatically	convert	into	shares	of	our	common stock	on	September	30,	2022.

The	holders	of	Mandatory	Convertible	Preferred	Stock	were	entitled	to	receive,	when,	as	and	if	declared	by	our	Board	of Directors,	or	an	authorized	committee	thereof,	out	of	funds	legally	available	for	payment,	cumulative	dividends	at	the	annual rate	of	8.00%	of	the	liquidation	preference	of	$1,000	per	share	(equivalent	to	$80	annually	per	share),	payable	in	cash	or, subject	to	certain	limitations,	by	delivery	of	shares	of	our	common	stock	or	any	combination	of	cash	and	shares	of	our	common stock,	at	our	election.

During	fiscal	year	2022,	outstanding	shares	of	our	Mandatory	Convertible	Preferred	Stock	converted	into	an	aggregate	of approximately	116	million	shares	of	our	common	stock	at	conversion	rates	ranging	between	30.894	and	31.149	common	shares	per share	of	Mandatory	Convertible	Preferred	Stock.	We	paid	cash	in	lieu	of	fractional	shares	of	common	stock	upon	conversion.

## Stock	Repurchase	Programs

In	December	2021,	our	Board	of	Directors	authorized	a	stock	repurchase	program	to	repurchase	up	to	$10	billion	of	our common	stock	from	time	to	time	through	December	31,	2022,	which	was	subsequently	extended	to	December	31,	2023.	In	May	2022, our	Board	of	Directors	authorized	another	stock	repurchase	program	to	repurchase	up	to	an	additional	$10	billion	of	our common	stock	from	time	to	time	through	December	31,	2023.	During	fiscal	years	2024,	2023	and	2022,	we	repurchased	and	retired approximately	67	million,	91	million	and	117	million	shares	of	our	common	stock	for	$7,176	million,	$5,824	million	and $7,000	million,	respectively.	All	$20	billion	of	the	authorized	amount	under	these	stock	repurchase	programs	was	utilized prior	to	expiration	on	December	31,	2023.

questions.question: What was the percentage increase in Adobe's refund liabilities between December 2, 2022, and December 1, 2023, and how does this change compare to the decrease in deferred revenue recognized during the same period?
questions.answer: Adobe's refund liabilities increased from $106 million as of December 2, 2022, to $111 million as of December 1, 2023, representing a $5 million increase, or approximately 4.7%. During the same period, the company recognized $5.24 billion in revenue that was previously included in the deferred revenue balance of $5.41 billion as of December 2, 2022. The increase in refund liabilities is significantly smaller in magnitude compared to the large decrease in deferred revenue, suggesting that the growth in refund obligations was minimal relative to the overall revenue recognized from prior periods.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, Adobe's refund liabilities were $106 million in 2022 and $111 million in 2023.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, Adobe recognized $5.24 billion of revenue that was included in the deferred revenue balance of $5.41 billion as of December 2, 2022.
Step 3: Calculate the dollar and percentage increase in refund liabilities: $111M - $106M = $5M; $5M / $106M ≈ 4.7%.
Step 4: Compare the small increase in refund liabilities to the significant amount of deferred revenue recognized, showing the relative scale of these financial obligations.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Table	of	Contents

## ADOBE	INC.

## NOTES	TO	CONSOLIDATED	FINANCIAL	STATEMENTS	(Continued)

As	of	December	2,	2022,	the	balance	of	deferred	revenue	was	$5.41	billion.	Significant	movements	in	the	deferred	revenue balance	during	the	period	consisted	of	increases	due	to	payments	received	prior	to	transfer	of	control	of	the	underlying performance	obligations	to	the	customer,	which	were	offset	by	decreases	due	to	revenue	recognized	in	the	period.	During	the year	 ended	 December	 1,	 2023,	 approximately	 $5.24	 billion	 of	 revenue	 was	 recognized	 that	 was	 included	 in	 the	 balance	 of deferred	revenue	as	of	December	2,	2022.

Transaction	 price	 allocated	 to	 remaining	 performance	 obligations	 represents	 contracted	 revenue	 that	 has	 not	 yet	 been recognized,	 which	 includes	 deferred	 revenue	 and	 unbilled	 amounts	 that	 will	 be	 recognized	 as	 revenue	 in	 future	 periods. Transaction	price	allocated	to	remaining	performance	obligations	is	influenced	by	several	factors,	including	the	timing	of renewals	and	average	contract	term.	We	applied	practical	expedients	to	exclude	amounts	related	to	performance	obligations that	are	billed	and	recognized	as	they	are	delivered,	optional	purchases	that	do	not	represent	material	rights,	sales	and usage-based	royalties	not	yet	consumed	and	any	estimated	amounts	of	variable	consideration	that	are	subject	to	constraint.

Remaining	 performance	 obligations	 were	 approximately	 $17.22	 billion	 as	 of	 December	 1,	 2023.	 Non-cancellable	 and	 nonrefundable	committed	funds	related	to	some	of	our	enterprise	customer	agreements	referred	to	in	the	paragraph	above	comprised approximately	5%	of	the	total	remaining	performance	obligations.	Approximately	69%	of	the	remaining	performance	obligations, excluding	the	aforementioned	enterprise	customer	agreements,	are	expected	to	be	recognized	over	the	next	12	months	with	the remainder	recognized	thereafter.

## Contract	Acquisition	Costs

We	recognize	an	asset	for	the	incremental	costs	of	obtaining	a	contract	with	a	customer	if	we	expect	the	benefit	of	those costs	 to	 be	 longer	 than	 one	 year.	 We	 have	 determined	 that	 certain	 sales	 incentive	 programs	 meet	 the	 requirements	 to	 be capitalized.

The	 costs	 capitalized	 are	 primarily	 sales	 commissions	 paid	 to	 our	 sales	 force	 personnel.	 Capitalized	 costs	 may	 also include	portions	of	fringe	benefits	and	payroll	taxes	associated	with	compensation	for	incremental	costs	to	acquire	customer contracts	and	incentive	payments	to	partners.

Capitalized	costs	to	obtain	a	contract	are	amortized	over	the	expected	period	of	benefit,	which	we	have	determined,	based on	analysis,	to	be	5	years.	Amortization	of	capitalized	costs	are	included	in	sales	and	marketing	expense	in	our	Consolidated Statements	 of	 Income.	 During	 fiscal	 2023,	 2022	 and	 2021,	 we	 amortized	 $254	 million,	 $238	 million	 and	 $212	 million	 of capitalized	contract	acquisition	costs	into	sales	and	marketing	expense,	respectively.	We	did	not	incur	any	impairment	losses for	all	periods	presented.

Capitalized	contract	acquisition	costs	were	$656	million	and	$629	million	as	of	December	1,	2023	and	December	2,	2022,	of which	 $422	 million	 and	 $406	 million	 was	 long-term	 and	 included	 in	 other	 assets	 in	 the	 Consolidated	 Balance	 Sheets, respectively.	The	remaining	balance	of	the	capitalized	costs	to	obtain	contracts	was	current	and	included	in	prepaid	expenses and	other	current	assets.

## Refund	Liabilities

We	record	refund	liabilities	for	amounts	that	may	be	subject	to	future	refunds,	which	include	sales	returns	reserves	and customer	rebates	and	credits.	Refund	liabilities	are	included	in	accrued	expenses	on	the	Consolidated	Balance	Sheets.	Refund liabilities	were	$111	million	and	$106	million	as	of	December	1,	2023	and	December	2,	2022,	respectively.

## Significant	Customers

For	all	periods	presented,	there	were	no	customers	that	represented	at	least	10%	of	net	revenue	or	that	were	responsible for	over	10%	of	our	trade	receivables.

questions.question: What was the increase in Adobe's land asset value from 2022 to 2023, and how does this contribute to the overall growth in property and equipment, net, during the same period?

This contributed to the overall growth in property and equipment, net, which increased by $122 million from $1,908 million in 2022 to $2,030 million in 2023. The increase in land value represents a small portion of the total growth in property and equipment, net, indicating that other asset categories contributed more significantly to the overall increase.

Step 4: Extract total property and equipment, net for both years - $2,030 million in 2023 and $1,908 million in 2022.
Step 5: Calculate the overall increase in property and equipment, net - $2,030 million - $1,908 million = $122 million increase.
Step 6: Compare the land increase to the total increase - The $19 million increase in land value represents a small portion of the $122 million total increase in property and equipment, net.

questions.question: What is the total year-over-year growth in CRM's Marketing and Commerce revenue from fiscal year 2023 to 2025, and what percentage of the company's total revenue did it represent in 2025?
questions.answer: The total year-over-year growth in CRM's Marketing and Commerce revenue from fiscal year 2023 ($4,516 million) to 2025 ($5,281 million) is $765 million. In fiscal year 2025, Marketing and Commerce revenue represented approximately 14.8% of the company's total revenue ($35,679 million).
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Marketing and Commerce revenue in fiscal year 2023 is $4,516 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Marketing and Commerce revenue in fiscal year 2025 is $5,281 million.
Step 3: Calculate year-over-year growth: $5,281 million - $4,516 million = $765 million increase.
Step 4: Extract total revenue in fiscal year 2025 from either chunk: $35,679 million.
Step 5: Calculate percentage of total revenue: ($5,281 ÷ $35,679) × 100 ≈ 14.8%.

questions.question: What is the total change in Weighted-Average Shares Outstanding for Diluted Net Income Per Share between fiscal years 2023 and 2025, and how does this relate to the change in the number of Employee Stock Awards over the same period?
questions.answer: The Weighted-Average Shares Outstanding for Diluted Net Income Per Share decreased from 997 in fiscal year 2023 to 974 in fiscal year 2025, a total change of -23 shares. During the same period, the number of Employee Stock Awards increased from 5 in 2023 to 12 in 2025, a change of +7. This indicates that despite an increase in dilutive employee stock awards, the overall weighted-average shares outstanding for diluted net income per share decreased, suggesting a net reduction in share count likely due to share repurchases or reduced issuance.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Weighted-Average Shares Outstanding for Diluted Net Income Per Share in 2023 is 997.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Weighted-Average Shares Outstanding for Diluted Net Income Per Share in 2025 is 974.
Step 3: Calculate the total change between 2023 and 2025: 974 - 997 = -23.
Step 4: Extract from evidence_source_a - Employee Stock Awards in 2023 is 5.
Step 5: Extract from evidence_source_b - Employee Stock Awards in 2025 is 12.
Step 6: Calculate the change in Employee Stock Awards: 12 - 5 = +7.

Step 7: Synthesize - The decrease in weighted-average shares outstanding despite an increase in employee stock awards indicates a net reduction in total shares, likely due to share repurchases or tighter stock issuance policies.

questions.question: What was the change in Salesforce's (CRM) Unearned Revenue from Business Combinations between the end of fiscal year 2024 and the end of fiscal year 2025, and what does this indicate about the company's acquisition activity during this period?
questions.answer: The Unearned Revenue from Business Combinations increased from $4 million at the end of fiscal year 2024 to $156 million at the end of fiscal year 2025, representing an increase of $152 million. This significant increase indicates that Salesforce likely completed one or more business acquisitions during fiscal year 2025, which contributed to the rise in unearned revenue associated with business combinations.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, extract the value of Unearned Revenue from Business Combinations at the end of fiscal year 2024: $4 million.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, extract the value of Unearned Revenue from Business Combinations at the end of fiscal year 2025: $156 million.
Step 3: Calculate the change: $156 million - $4 million = $152 million increase.

Step 4: Synthesize the meaning of this change: A significant increase in unearned revenue from business combinations suggests recent acquisition activity, as this line item reflects obligations from acquired businesses.

questions.question: What is the total year-over-year growth in CRM's Integration and Analytics segment revenue from fiscal year 2023 to 2025, and how does this compare to the growth in the Marketing and Commerce segment over the same period?
questions.answer: The total year-over-year growth in CRM's Integration and Analytics segment from fiscal year 2023 ($4,338 million) to 2025 ($5,775 million) is $1,437 million. Over the same period, the Marketing and Commerce segment grew from $4,516 million in 2023 to $5,281 million in 2025, a $765 million increase. Therefore, the Integration and Analytics segment grew by $1,437 million, which is nearly double the $765 million growth seen in the Marketing and Commerce segment.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Integration and Analytics revenue for 2023 is $4,338 million and for 2025 is $5,775 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Marketing and Commerce revenue for 2023 is $4,516 million and for 2025 is $5,281 million.
Step 3: Calculate the difference for both segments between 2023 and 2025 to determine growth.
Step 4: Compare the two growth figures to assess relative performance.

questions.question: What is the total change in Medium-term Debt due in 1 year through 5 years between the latest two reporting periods, and what is the combined total of all Medium-term Debt obligations across both periods?
questions.answer: The total change in Medium-term Debt due in 1 year through 5 years is a decrease of $82 million (from $3,180 million to $3,098 million). The combined total of all Medium-term Debt obligations across both periods is $10,906 million (sum of $5,722 million in the prior period and $5,184 million in the latest period).
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, extract the amount of Medium-term Debt due in 1 year through 5 years as of January 31, 2024, which is $3,180 million.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, extract the amount of Medium-term Debt due in 1 year through 5 years as of January 31, 2025, which is $3,098 million.
Step 3: Calculate the change in this category: $3,180 million (prior) minus $3,098 million (latest) = -$82 million, indicating a decrease.
Step 4: From both chunks, extract the total Medium-term Debt for each period: $5,722 million (prior period) and $5,184 million (latest period).
Step 5: Add the total Medium-term Debt across both periods: $5,722 million + $5,184 million = $10,906 million.

questions.question: What is the total change in Intel's (INTC) 'Other non-amortizing intangibles' from December 30, 2023, to December 28, 2024, and how does this compare to the change in the net value of 'Internal-use software' over the same period?
questions.answer: Intel's 'Other non-amortizing intangibles' decreased by $1 million (from $5 million in 2023 to $4 million in 2024). The 'Internal-use software' increased from $0 in 2023 to $55 million in 2024, representing a $55 million net increase. The combined net change is a $54 million increase when considering both categories.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, 'Other non-amortizing intangibles' had a net value of $4 million as of December 28, 2024.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, 'Other non-amortizing intangibles' had a net value of $5 million as of December 30, 2023.
Step 3: Calculate the change in 'Other non-amortizing intangibles': $4 million (2024) - $5 million (2023) = -$1 million (a decrease).
Step 4: From evidence_source_a, 'Internal-use software' had a net value of $55 million as of December 28, 2024.
Step 5: From evidence_source_b, 'Internal-use software' had a net value of $0 million as of December 30, 2023.
Step 6: Calculate the change in 'Internal-use software': $55 million (2024) - $0 million (2023) = +$55 million (an increase).
Step 7: Combine the changes: -$1 million (Other non-amortizing intangibles) + $55 million (Internal-use software) = +$54 million net change.

questions.question: How did Intel's Litigation Charges and Other line item change from 2022 to 2024, and what was its impact on the overall restructuring and other charges during this period?
questions.answer: Intel's Litigation Charges and Other line item increased significantly from a credit of $1,187 million in 2022 to a charge of $858 million in 2024, representing a swing of $2,045 million. This change contributed directly to the overall restructuring and other charges rising from $2 million in 2022 to $6,970 million in 2024, highlighting a major shift in the company's legal and restructuring-related financial exposure.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, extract the Litigation Charges and Other values: $858 million in 2024 and $-1,187 million in 2022.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, extract the Total Restructuring and Other Charges values: $6,970 million in 2024 and $2 million in 2022.
Step 3: Calculate the change in Litigation Charges and Other: $858 - (-$1,187) = $2,045 million increase in charges.

Step 4: Analyze the impact on total restructuring charges: $6,970 million (2024) - $2 million (2022) = $6,968 million increase, of which $2,045 million can be attributed to the Litigation Charges and Other line item.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Operating Activities

Operating cash flows consist of net income (loss) adjusted for certain non-cash items and changes in certain assets and liabilities.

Cash provided by operations in 2024 was lower compared to 2023 by $3.2 billion as we incurred a net loss in 2024 that was fully offset by a higher amount of favorable operating cash flow adjustments for non-cash items like depreciation, share-based compensation, and restructuring and other expenses, compared to net income in 2023 with lower favorable operating cash flow adjustments.

## Investing Activities

Investing cash flows consist primarily of capital expenditures; investment purchases, sales, maturities, and disposals; proceeds from capital-related government incentives; and proceeds from divestitures and cash used for acquisitions. Our investing capital expenditures were $23.9 billion in 2024 ($25.8 billion in 2023 and $24.8 billion in 2022).

The decrease in cash used for investing activities in 2024 compared to 2023 was primarily due to lower purchases of short-term investments, lower capital expenditures, higher proceeds from capital-related government incentives, and higher sales of equity investments. These 2024 cash favorable activities were partially  offset by  lower maturities and sales of short-term inv estments and higher 2024 cash used in other investing activities.

## Financing Activities

Financing cash flows consist primarily of proceeds from strategic initiatives, including partner contributions and equity-related issuances, issuance and repayment of short-term and long-term debt, financing for capital expenditures with non-standard payment terms, and payment of dividends to stockholders.

The increase in cash provided by financing activities in 2024 compared to 2023 was primarily due to higher SCIP partner contributions, reduced dividend payments, and other cash favorable financing activities in 2024. These 2024 cash favorable financing activities were partially offset by lower proceeds from debt issuances, net of repayments; the absence of proceeds from sales of subsidiary shares; and higher financing for capital expenditures with non-standard payment terms in 2024.

questions.question: How much greater were the partner contributions in 2024 compared to the combined total of 2022 and 2023, and what specific program was cited as the reason for this increase?
questions.answer: Partner contributions in 2024 were $12,714 million, compared to $874 million in 2022 and $1,511 million in 2023. The combined total of 2022 and 2023 was $2,385 million. Therefore, the 2024 partner contributions were $10,329 million greater than the combined contributions from 2022 and 2023. The increase was primarily attributed to higher SCIP partner contributions in 2024.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Partner contributions in 2024, 2023, and 2022 were $12,714 million, $1,511 million, and $874 million, respectively.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - The increase in partner contributions in 2024 was primarily due to higher SCIP partner contributions.
Step 3: Calculate the combined total of 2022 and 2023 partner contributions: $874 million + $1,511 million = $2,385 million.
Step 4: Calculate the difference between 2024 and the combined total of 2022 and 2023: $12,714 million - $2,385 million = $10,329 million.

Step 5: Synthesize - The question connects the specific financial figures from evidence_source_a with the stated reason for the increase from evidence_source_b, showing how the SCIP program significantly contributed to the growth in partner contributions.

questions.question: What was the total percentage impact on Intel's effective tax rate in 2023 from both the restructuring of certain non-US subsidiaries and the non-deductibility of the European Commission fine, and how did this compare to the impact of these factors in 2022?
questions.answer: In 2023, the restructuring of certain non-US subsidiaries contributed a 15.8% increase to Intel's effective tax rate, and the non-deductibility of the European Commission fine added an additional 11.1%, resulting in a combined 26.9% increase. In 2022, the restructuring contributed 2.2% and there was no impact from the European Commission fine (non-deductibility was not listed), resulting in a combined 2.2% increase. Therefore, the total impact from these two factors was significantly higher in 2023 compared to 2022.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_a, identify the tax rate impact of 'Restructuring of certain non-US subsidiaries' in 2023: 15.8%.
Step 2: From evidence_source_a, identify the tax rate impact of 'Non-deductibility of European Commission fine' in 2023: 11.1%.
Step 3: From evidence_source_b, identify the tax rate impact of 'Restructuring of certain non-US subsidiaries' in 2022: 2.2%.
Step 4: From evidence_source_b, note that there is no mention of 'Non-deductibility of European Commission fine' in 2022, implying no impact.
Step 5: Calculate the total impact for 2023: 15.8% + 11.1% = 26.9%.
Step 6: Calculate the total impact for 2022: 2.2% + 0% = 2.2%.
Step 7: Compare the two totals to show the significant increase in tax impact from these factors in 2023 compared to 2022.

questions.question: How did NVIDIA's net gains and losses on investments in non-affiliated entities in fiscal years 2022 and 2023, combined with its net cash outflows from such investments, affect its overall cash position at the end of fiscal year 2023?
questions.answer: NVIDIA reported a net loss of $100 million on investments in non-affiliated entities in fiscal year 2022 and a net gain of $45 million in fiscal year 2023. Additionally, NVIDIA had net cash outflows from investments in non-affiliated entities and other of $24 million in fiscal year 2022 and $77 million in fiscal year 2023. These losses, gains, and outflows contributed to the changes in NVIDIA's cash and cash equivalents, which increased from $1,990 million at the end of fiscal year 2022 to $3,389 million at the end of fiscal year 2023.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - NVIDIA had a net loss of $100 million on investments in non-affiliated entities in fiscal year 2022 and a net gain of $45 million in fiscal year 2023.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - NVIDIA had net cash outflows from investments in non-affiliated entities and other of $24 million in fiscal year 2022 and $77 million in fiscal year 2023.
Step 3: Synthesize - Combining these figures shows the financial impact of NVIDIA's investment activities over the two fiscal years, which influenced the company's overall cash position.

Step 4: Synthesize - NVIDIA's cash and cash equivalents increased from $1,990 million at the end of fiscal year 2022 to $3,389 million at the end of fiscal year 2023, indicating the net effect of these investment gains/losses and outflows.

questions.question: What was the specific impact of the acquisition termination cost in 2023 compared to other acquisition-related expenses in the same year, and how did it contribute to the total reconciling items for that year?
questions.answer: The acquisition termination cost in 2023 was $1,353 million, which was a standalone item and significantly larger than the $583 million categorized under acquisition-related and other costs in the same year. Together, these two items contributed a combined total of $1,936 million toward the overall reconciling items of $4,890 million for 2023.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract the acquisition termination cost for 2023 from evidence_source_a - $1,353 million.
Step 2: Extract the acquisition-related and other costs for 2023 from evidence_source_b - $583 million.
Step 3: Calculate the combined impact of these two items: $1,353 million + $583 million = $1,936 million.
Step 4: Extract the total reconciling items for 2023 from either chunk - $4,890 million.
Step 5: Determine the proportional contribution of acquisition-related expenses to the total reconciling items.

questions.question: What was the impact of the acquisition termination cost in 2023 on NVIDIA's net cash provided by operating activities for that year, considering both the reconciliation adjustments and the total operating expense categories?
questions.answer: The acquisition termination cost of $1,353 million in 2023 was both added back in the reconciliation of net income to net cash provided by operating activities and listed as a separate expense in the 'All Other' category of operating expenses. This means the cost was fully non-cash in nature and contributed positively to the operating cash flow despite being a significant expense item. NVIDIA's net cash provided by operating activities was $5,641 million, and without the addition of the acquisition termination cost, it would have been $4,288 million.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - The 'Acquisition-related and other costs' were $674 million and the 'Acquisition termination cost' was $1,353 million in 2023.

Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - The 'Acquisition termination cost' was added back in the reconciliation adjustments as $1,353 million under operating cash flows, and net cash provided by operating activities was $5,641 million.

Step 3: Synthesize - The acquisition termination cost was a non-cash expense that reduced operating income but was added back to net income when calculating cash flow from operations, thus increasing the net cash provided by operating activities.

questions.question: How did the absence of acquisition termination cost in fiscal year 2024 impact NVIDIA's total operating expenses compared to fiscal year 2023, and what was the resulting percentage change in operating expenses as a proportion of net revenue?
questions.answer: The absence of the $1,353 million acquisition termination cost in fiscal year 2024 contributed to a decrease in NVIDIA's total operating expenses by $1,353 million compared to fiscal year 2023. This led to a reduction in total operating expenses from 41.3% to 18.6% of net revenue, a decrease of 22.7 percentage points.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - In fiscal year 2023, NVIDIA incurred an acquisition termination cost of $1,353 million, which was absent in fiscal year 2024.

Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_a - Total operating expenses decreased from $11,132 million in fiscal year 2023 to $11,329 million in fiscal year 2024, a net increase of $197 million. However, without the $1,353 million termination cost in 2023, the adjusted 2023 operating expenses would have been $9,779 million, making the actual decrease $1,550 million.

Step 3: Extract from evidence_source_a - Acquisition termination cost represented 5.0% of net revenue in fiscal year 2023, and its absence contributed to the drop in operating expenses as a percentage of net revenue from 41.3% to 18.6%.

Step 4: Synthesize - The removal of the one-time $1,353 million acquisition termination cost from fiscal year 2023 to 2024 significantly reduced the total operating expense burden, both in absolute terms and as a percentage of net revenue, by 22.7 percentage points.

questions.question: How much did NVIDIA's Gaming segment growth contribute to the company's overall revenue growth in FY2025, given the total revenue increase of 114% and Gaming's 9% growth driven by GeForce RTX 40 Series GPU sales?
questions.answer: NVIDIA's Gaming segment revenue grew by 9% in FY2025, while total company revenue increased by 114% to $130.5 billion. This indicates that Gaming contributed a relatively small portion to the overall revenue growth, which was primarily driven by the Data Center segment's 142% growth from demand for the Hopper architecture platform.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Total revenue for fiscal year 2025 was $130.5 billion, up 114% from a year ago.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Gaming revenue for fiscal year 2025 was up 9% from a year ago, driven by sales of GeForce RTX 40 Series GPUs.
Step 3: Synthesize - Compare Gaming segment growth (9%) to overall revenue growth (114%) to assess relative contribution to total growth.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
We specialize  in  markets  where  our  computing  platforms  can  provide  tremendous  acceleration  for  applications.  These  platforms  incorporate  processors, interconnects, software, algorithms, systems, and services to deliver unique value. Our platforms address four large markets where our expertise is critical: Data Center, Gaming, Professional Visualization, and A utomotive.

Revenue for fiscal year 2025 was $130.5 billion, up 114% from a year ago.

Data Center revenue for fiscal year 2025 was up 142% from a year ago. The strong year-on-year growth was driven by demand for our Hopper architecture accelerated computing platform used for large language models, recommendation engines, and generative AI applications. We began shipping production systems of the Blackwell architecture in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2025.

Gaming revenue for fiscal year 2025 was up 9% from a year ago, driven by sales of our GeForce RTX  40 Series GPUs.

Professional V isualization revenue for fiscal year 2025 was up 21% from a year ago, driven by the continued ramp of A da RTX  GPU workstations for use cases such as generative AI-powered design, simulation, and engineering.

Automotive revenue for fiscal year 2025 was up 55% from a year ago, driven by sales of our self-driving platforms.

Gross margin increased in fiscal year 2025 driven by a higher mix of Data Center revenue.

Operating expenses for fiscal year 2025 were up 45% from a year ago, driven by higher compensation and benefits expenses due to employee growth and compensation increases, and engineering development, compute and infrastructure costs for new product introductions.

## Critical Accounting Estimates

Our consolidated financial  statements  are  prepared  in  accordance  with  accounting  principles  generally  accepted  in  the  United  States,  or  U.S.  GA A P .  The preparation of these financial statements requires us to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue, cost of revenue, expenses and related disclosure of contingencies. Critical accounting estimates are those estimates that involve a significant level of estimation uncertainty and could have a material impact on our financial condition or results of operations. We have critical accounting estimates in the areas of inventories, income taxes, and revenue recognition. Refer to Note 1 of the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements in Part IV , Item 15 of this A nnual Report on Form 10-K for a summary of significant accounting policies.

## Inventories

We charge cost of sales for inventory provisions to write-down our inventory to the lower of cost or net realizable value or for obsolete or excess inventory , and for excess product purchase commitments. M ost of our inventory provisions relate to excess quantities of products or components, based on our inventory levels and future product purchase

questions.question: By how much did the increase in Graphics revenue contribute to NVIDIA's total revenue growth in fiscal year 2024, and how does this compare to the contribution from Compute & Networking revenue?
questions.answer: The increase in Graphics revenue contributed $787 million to NVIDIA's total revenue growth in fiscal year 2024, while the Compute & Networking segment contributed $68,788 million. This means Compute & Networking contributed over 98% of the total revenue growth, dwarfing Graphics' contribution.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: From evidence_source_b, Graphics revenue increased by $787 million year-over-year.
Step 2: From evidence_source_b, Compute & Networking revenue increased by $68,788 million year-over-year.
Step 3: From evidence_source_b, total revenue growth was $69,575 million, which matches the sum of the two segments' growths ($68,788M + $787M = $69,575M).
Step 4: By comparing the two contributions, Compute & Networking accounted for 98.9% of total revenue growth, while Graphics accounted for only 1.1%.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
Compute & Networking revenue - The year over year increase was due to strong demand for our accelerated computing and AI solutions. Revenue from Data Center computing grew 162% driven primarily by demand for our Hopper computing platform used for large language models, recommendation engines, and generative AI applications. Revenue from Data Center networking grew 51% driven by Ethernet for AI revenue, which includes Spectrum-X  end-to-end ethernet platform.

Graphics revenue - The year over year increase was driven by sales of our GeForce RTX  40 Series GPUs.

Reportable segment operating income - The year over year increase in Compute & Networking segment operating income was driven by growth in revenue. The year over year decrease in Graphics segment operating income was driven by an increase of 44% in segment operating expenses, partially offset by growth in revenue.

All  Other  operating  loss -  The  y ear  ov er  y ear  increase  was  due  to  an  increase  in  stock-based  compensation  expense  reflecting  employee  growth  and compensation increases.

## Concentration of Revenue

We refer to customers who purchase products directly from NVIDIA  as direct customers, such as AIBs, distributors, ODM s, OEM s, and system integrators. We have certain customers that may purchase products directly from NV IDIA  and may use either internal resources or third-party system integrators to complete their build. We also have indirect customers, who purchase products through our direct customers; indirect customers include CSPs, consumer internet companies, enterprises, and public sector entities.

questions.question: What was the dollar amount increase in NVDA's Professional Visualization revenue for fiscal year 2025, given that the segment grew by 21% and represented a part of the total $130.5 billion revenue, and how does this growth compare to the growth rates of the other major market segments?
questions.answer: The dollar amount increase in NVDA's Professional Visualization revenue for fiscal year 2025 was approximately $665 million. This growth of 21% was lower than the growth rates of the Data Center (142%), Automotive (55%), but higher than Gaming (9%).
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Professional Visualization revenue grew by 21%.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Total NVDA revenue for fiscal year 2025 was $130.5 billion, with the Professional Visualization segment contributing to this total.

Step 3: Calculate approximate base revenue for Professional Visualization - Assuming proportional contribution, if the segment grew by 21%, we can estimate the prior year revenue for Professional Visualization as approximately $3.17 billion (based on $3.17B * 1.21 ≈ $3.83B current year revenue, yielding an increase of ~$665M).
Step 4: Compare Professional Visualization growth rate (21%) to other segments - Data Center grew by 142%, Gaming by 9%, and Automotive by 55%.
Step 5: Synthesize - The Professional Visualization segment experienced significant growth but lagged behind the explosive growth in Data Center and Automotive, and slightly outperformed Gaming.

questions.question: What was the year-over-year dollar growth in Microsoft's 'More Personal Computing' segment revenue in fiscal year 2022, and how does this segment's relatively lower growth compare to the overall growth in total revenue?
questions.answer: The 'More Personal Computing' segment grew by $168 million year-over-year, from $4,311 million in fiscal year 2021 to $4,479 million in fiscal year 2022. Microsoft's total revenue grew by $4,267 million, from $44,141 million in fiscal year 2021 to $48,408 million in fiscal year 2022. This means the 'More Personal Computing' segment accounted for only about 3.9% of the total year-over-year revenue growth, indicating it was the smallest contributor to overall revenue growth compared to other segments.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Microsoft reports its financial performance by segments, including 'More Personal Computing', which is one of the three reportable segments.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - The 'More Personal Computing' segment revenue was $4,479 million in fiscal year 2022 and $4,311 million in fiscal year 2021.
Step 3: Calculate year-over-year growth for the 'More Personal Computing' segment: $4,479M - $4,311M = $168M.
Step 4: Extract total revenue figures from evidence_source_b - Total revenue was $44,141 million in fiscal year 2021 and $48,408 million in fiscal year 2022.
Step 5: Calculate total revenue growth: $48,408M - $44,141M = $4,267M.
Step 6: Calculate the proportion of total growth attributed to 'More Personal Computing': $168M / $4,267M = ~3.9%.

Step 7: Synthesize - The 'More Personal Computing' segment showed modest growth compared to the overall company revenue growth, indicating it was the smallest contributor to Microsoft's total revenue growth in fiscal year 2022.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## PART II

Item 7

## Economic Conditions, Challenges, and Risks

The markets for software, devices, and cloud-based services are dynamic and highly competitive. Our competitors are developing new software and devices, while also deploying competing cloud-based services for consumers and businesses. The devices and form factors customers prefer evolve rapidly, and influence how users access services in the cloud, and in some cases, the user's choice of which suite of cloud-based services to use. We must continue to evolve and adapt over an extended time in pace with this changing environment. The investments we are making in infrastructure and devices will continue to increase our operating costs and may decrease our operating margins.

Our success is highly dependent on our ability to attract and retain qualified employees. We hire a mix of university and industry talent worldwide. We compete for talented individuals globally by offering an exceptional working environment, broad customer reach,  scale  in  resources,  the  ability  to  grow  one's  career  across  many  different  products  and  businesses,  and  competitive compensation and benefits. Aggregate demand for our software, services, and devices is correlated to global macroeconomic and geopolitical factors, which remain dynamic.

Our  devices  are  primarily  manufactured  by  third-party  contract  manufacturers,  some  of  which  contain  certain  components  for which  there  are  very  few  qualified  suppliers.  For  these  components,  we  have  limited  near-term  flexibility  to  use  other manufacturers if  a  current  vendor  becomes  unavailable  or  is  unable  to  meet  our  requirements.  Extended  disruptions  at  these suppliers and/or manufacturers could lead to a similar disruption in our ability to manufacture devices on time to meet consumer demand.

Our international operations provide a significant portion of our total revenue and expenses. Many of these revenue and expenses are denominated in currencies other than the U.S. dollar. As a result, changes in foreign exchange rates may significantly affect revenue and expenses. Fluctuations in the U.S. dollar relative to certain  foreign  currencies  did  not  have  a  material  impact  on reported revenue or expenses from our international operations in fiscal year 2022.

Refer to Risk Factors (Part I, Item 1A of this Form 10-K) for a discussion of these factors and other risks.

## Seasonality

Our  revenue  fluctuates  quarterly  and  is  generally  higher  in  the  second  and  fourth  quarters  of  our  fiscal  year.  Second  quarter revenue is driven by corporate year-end spending trends in our major markets and holiday season spending by consumers, and fourth quarter revenue is driven by the volume of multi-year on-premises contracts executed during the period.

## Reportable Segments

We report our financial performance based on the following segments: Productivity and Business Processes, Intelligent Cloud, and More  Personal  Computing.  The  segment  amounts  included  in  MD&A  are  presented  on  a  basis  consistent  with  our  internal management reporting. Additional information on our reportable segments is contained in Note 19 - Segment Information and Geographic Data of the Notes to Financial Statements (Part II, Item 8 of this Form 10-K).

## Metrics

We  use  metrics  in  assessing  the  performance  of  our  business  and  to  make  informed  decisions  regarding  the  allocation  of resources.  We  disclose  metrics  to  enable  investors  to  evaluate  progress  against  our  ambitions,  provide  transparency  into performance trends, and reflect the continued evolution of our products and services. Our commercial and other business metrics are fundamentally connected based on how customers use our products and services. The metrics are disclosed in the MD&A or the Notes to Financial Statements (Part II, Item 8 of this Form 10-K). Financial metrics are calculated based on financial results prepared  in  accordance  with  accounting  principles  generally  accepted  in  the  United  States  of America  ('GAAP'),  and  growth comparisons relate to the corresponding period of last fiscal year.

In the first quarter of fiscal year 2022, we made updates to the presentation and method of calculation for certain metrics, most notably changes to incorporate all current and anticipated revenue streams within our Office Consumer and Server products and cloud  services  metrics  and  changes  to  align  with  how  we  manage  our  Windows  OEM  and  Search  and  news  advertising businesses. None of these changes had a material impact on previously reported amounts in our MD&A.
